text:
<!here> hello and welcome to our second april AMA! please welcome <@U01SFN80R26> (content lead) and <@U01UCANCKPW> (technical product marketing) from Airtable. this tool is sort of insane. airtable is leading the no-code trend and is an awesome for non-technical folks (like me!) to build amazing workflows.
this is a great chance to ask questions about workflow, automation, project management, team alignment, task management and so much more. here are a few tutorials that <@U01SFN80R26>, <@U01UCANCKPW> and i recorded together:
• <https://superpath.co/blog/manage-content-requests-in-airtable|How to Manage Company-Wide Content Requests in Airtable>
• <https://superpath.co/blog/how-to-build-a-functional-marketing-plan-in-airtable|How to Build a Functional Marketing Plan in Airtable>
• <https://superpath.co/blog/how-to-give-your-cmo-insight-into-your-content-marketing-workflow-with-airtable|How to Give Your CMO Insight Into Your Content Marketing Workflow with Airtable>
also, if you're interested, you can get a $500 credit towards airtable's plus or pro version. just use this link: <http://airtable.com/superpath|airtable.com/superpath>
i'll queue up the first question :sunglasses:

elements.text: hello and welcome to our second april AMA! please welcome
(content lead) and

(technical product marketing) from Airtable. this tool is sort of insane. airtable is leading the no-code trend and is an awesome for non-technical folks (like me!) to build amazing workflows.
this is a great chance to ask questions about workflow, automation, project management, team alignment, task management and so much more. here are a few tutorials that
and i recorded together:
How to Manage Company-Wide Content Requests in Airtable
How to Build a Functional Marketing Plan in Airtable
How to Give Your CMO Insight Into Your Content Marketing Workflow with Airtable
also, if you're interested, you can get a $500 credit towards airtable's plus or pro version. just use this link:
airtable.com/superpath
i'll queue up the first question

text: Woohoo! Thanks <@UJG9WTEKG>! We're stoked to be here. I'm on my SECOND cup of coffee now, so ready for anything...

elements.text: Woohoo! Thanks
! We're stoked to be here. I'm on my SECOND cup of coffee now, so ready for anything...

text: my first question is about content strategy. airtable has basically infinite use cases. how do you even begin to plan a content calendar???

elements.text: my first question is about content strategy. airtable has basically infinite use cases. how do you even begin to plan a content calendar???

text: HA. Beginning is actually the hardest part. :joy:

elements.text: HA. Beginning is actually the hardest part.

text: :wave: <@U01SFN80R26> — you're a content marketing veteran who's seen it evolve from the early days. What's changed in your approach to building content engines the most? And what's stayed relatively the same?

elements.text: — you're a content marketing veteran who's seen it evolve from the early days. What's changed in your approach to building content engines the most? And what's stayed relatively the same?

text: We start with focus areas pulled from across the company. My team uses Airtable (natch) to directly solicit inputs from leadership on basically every team at the company

elements.text: We start with focus areas pulled from across the company. My team uses Airtable (natch) to directly solicit inputs from leadership on basically every team at the company

text: Where do you see content marketing as a whole headed in the next 5 years? Also :wave:

elements.text: Where do you see content marketing as a whole headed in the next 5 years? Also

text: Ideally (not always) we have a few use cases that the whole marketing team is focusing on at the same time, which makes everything more efficient. For example, right now we're focusing on content operations and marketing teams, so it's all very meta

elements.text: Ideally (not always) we have a few use cases that the whole marketing team is focusing on at the same time, which makes everything more efficient. For example, right now we're focusing on content operations and marketing teams, so it's all very meta

text: Yayyyy! Hi Ronnie!!!!

elements.text: Yayyyy! Hi Ronnie!!!!

text: How does content marketing collaborate with product marketing at Airtable?

elements.text: How does content marketing collaborate with product marketing at Airtable?

text: oo great question. esp at a company like airtable where the product is so accessbile

elements.text: oo great question. esp at a company like airtable where the product is so accessbile

text: I would say the biggest change for me has been PATIENCE. Some tactics give you results overnight, but most of what you'll ship really proves it's worth (or lack thereof) over time

elements.text: I would say the biggest change for me has been PATIENCE. Some tactics give you results overnight, but most of what you'll ship really proves it's worth (or lack thereof) over time

text: These days i'm thinking: OK, I've got to invest early in tactics like SEO that take a long time to start showing results, so then I've got to balance that with conversion-driven campaigns that will drive results fast...basically need to do a little of everything

elements.text: These days i'm thinking: OK, I've got to invest early in tactics like SEO that take a long time to start showing results, so then I've got to balance that with conversion-driven campaigns that will drive results fast...basically need to do a little of everything

text: that's cool. i love that you can constantly dog food the product

elements.text: that's cool. i love that you can constantly dog food the product

text: :raised_hands::skin-tone-2:

Oh ALSO: the thing I edit/review for MOST these days is point of view. We've been talking about how crowded the content space is for years now, but it's only recently hit home for me that so much content has value, but no perspective. My most frequent comment on my team's work these days is "What's the unique POV here?"

elements.text: Oh ALSO: the thing I edit/review for MOST these days is point of view. We've been talking about how crowded the content space is for years now, but it's only recently hit home for me that so much content has value, but no perspective. My most frequent comment on my team's work these days is "What's the unique POV here?"

text: Hi Tommy!!! of COURSE you're here :heart:

elements.text: Hi Tommy!!! of COURSE you're here

text: My glib answer is "everything on TikTok"

elements.text: My glib answer is "everything on TikTok"

text: but in all seriousness, short-form, low production value, deliver the goods in the most direct way possible

elements.text: but in all seriousness, short-form, low production value, deliver the goods in the most direct way possible

text: That's the 2 year plan. In 5 years we'll all be eating radioactive cockroaches right?

elements.text: That's the 2 year plan. In 5 years we'll all be eating radioactive cockroaches right?

text: YES such a good question. This has been different at every company I've worked on, but on my team now we are in serious lockstep with the PMMs at all tiimes

elements.text: YES such a good question. This has been different at every company I've worked on, but on my team now we are in serious lockstep with the PMMs at all tiimes

text: We plan quarters together based on their product roadmap, positioning updates, and focus areas

elements.text: We plan quarters together based on their product roadmap, positioning updates, and focus areas

text: one of the tutorials videos we made was about fielding internal content requests. does the airtable content team work sort of like an internal agency? or do you just support other teams who also create content?

elements.text: one of the tutorials videos we made was about fielding internal content requests. does the airtable content team work sort of like an internal agency? or do you just support other teams who also create content?

text: <@U01SFN80R26> We have a similar challenge/opportunity at Miro...and a similar approach to calendar planning. We should chat sometime! (We also use Airtable for our content inventory. Would be great to get some pro tips)

elements.text: We have a similar challenge/opportunity at Miro...and a similar approach to calendar planning. We should chat sometime! (We also use Airtable for our content inventory. Would be great to get some pro tips)

text: Everything PMM ships is either written or produced my by team, depending on the level of product depth — the deeper it is, the more likely that PMM is driving and Content is reviewing. Higher in the funnel is likely to be the opposotie

elements.text: Everything PMM ships is either written or produced my by team, depending on the level of product depth — the deeper it is, the more likely that PMM is driving and Content is reviewing. Higher in the funnel is likely to be the opposotie

text: :joy: I love it!

elements.text: I love it!

text: My team also works on in-product, educational content, so as you'd imagine that requires a ton of alignment with PMM (esp compared to something higher in the funnel)

elements.text: My team also works on in-product, educational content, so as you'd imagine that requires a ton of alignment with PMM (esp compared to something higher in the funnel)

text: Hey <@U01SFN80R26>, thanks for doing this AMA! I’m sure you’ve seen a lot of cool use cases for Airtable. What have been some of your favorite/most creative that might be non-obvious, but you wish they picked up more traction among content marketers like us?

elements.text: Hey

, thanks for doing this AMA! I’m sure you’ve seen a lot of cool use cases for Airtable. What have been some of your favorite/most creative that might be non-obvious, but you wish they picked up more traction among content marketers like us?

text: Oooh good question. We have kind of a hybrid model — 50ish % of what we do is in the agency model, producing requests that come through from other teams

elements.text: Oooh good question. We have kind of a hybrid model — 50ish % of what we do is in the agency model, producing requests that come through from other teams

text: the other half comes from our own analysis of past performance, topics we think will resonate, ideas that come out of brainstorms, etc

elements.text: the other half comes from our own analysis of past performance, topics we think will resonate, ideas that come out of brainstorms, etc

text: My team is also pretty senior and knows the product inside and out, so they have a strong voice in strategy conversations

elements.text: My team is also pretty senior and knows the product inside and out, so they have a strong voice in strategy conversations

text:
There seems to be a trend in content marketing that I can only describe as "build a media company" in which the content marketing function is becoming an in-house publishing and production house that pumps out everything from documentaries, feature films, and books.

What's your hot take? Do you perhaps see that potentially being the future of content marketing at Airtable?

elements.text:
There seems to be a trend in content marketing that I can only describe as "build a media company" in which the content marketing function is becoming an in-house publishing and production house that pumps out everything from documentaries, feature films, and books.

What's your hot take? Do you perhaps see that potentially being the future of content marketing at Airtable?

text: hey <@U01SFN80R26>! could you talk about the advantages of using airtable for content pipeline tracking vs a more specialized tool? also, do you have any advice on what to do as your team grows? i find airtable can be intimidating for new team members who haven't been part of the evolution of using airtable as a tool

! could you talk about the advantages of using airtable for content pipeline tracking vs a more specialized tool? also, do you have any advice on what to do as your team grows? i find airtable can be intimidating for new team members who haven't been part of the evolution of using airtable as a tool

text: At Airtable my team has taken the same concept, added a bunch of cool automations and formulas, and made it part of our workflow. It's...dope.

elements.text: At Airtable my team has taken the same concept, added a bunch of cool automations and formulas, and made it part of our workflow. It's...dope.

text: WHOA

elements.text: WHOA

text: I basically love any use of automations to make content workflows less painful.

elements.text: I basically love any use of automations to make content workflows less painful.

text: Ughhhhhh. This one is tough. I feel like this trend keeps coming and going...there was a minute when every brand had their own media publications (thinking Casper, Airbnb, etc)

elements.text: Ughhhhhh. This one is tough. I feel like this trend keeps coming and going...there was a minute when every brand had their own media publications (thinking Casper, Airbnb, etc)

text: <@UJG9WTEKG> that's one of the best parts about working on the marketing team as technical PMM on a product like Airtable. I get a firsthand look at how our teams are using the product, and try to create best-practices and repeatable workflows for other teams to use. Since it's easy to change without breaking existing workflows, we're always trying something new

elements.text: that's one of the best parts about working on the marketing team as technical PMM on a product like Airtable. I get a firsthand look at how our teams are using the product, and try to create best-practices and repeatable workflows for other teams to use. Since it's easy to change without breaking existing workflows, we're always trying something new

text: And I kind of love it, because I love all kinds of content and I have worked with so many smart and talented content creators within tech companies (present company included)

elements.text: And I kind of love it, because I love all kinds of content and I have worked with so many smart and talented content creators within tech companies (present company included)

text: BUT I also feel like there's something inherently off about brands being the major creators of art?

elements.text: BUT I also feel like there's something inherently off about brands being the major creators of art?

text: Like, shouldn't art be produced by groups and individuals for its own sake?

elements.text: Like, shouldn't art be produced by groups and individuals for its own sake?

text: Do we lose something when the majority of art has a  financial incentive? IDK

elements.text: Do we lose something when the majority of art has a  financial incentive? IDK

text: What do you think <@UUH2EB134>?

elements.text: What do you think

text: <@UJG9WTEKG> I'm beginning to feel like this should be a panel discussion at the first ever Superpath conference :wink:

elements.text: I'm beginning to feel like this should be a panel discussion at the first ever Superpath conference

text: :eyes:
Oh yeah love this question. So I'm NOT going to say anything disparaging about specialized tools because I know they work well for some teams

elements.text: Oh yeah love this question. So I'm NOT going to say anything disparaging about specialized tools because I know they work well for some teams

text: i've thought a lot about this. it will happen at some point!

elements.text: i've thought a lot about this. it will happen at some point!

text: i even came up with a name for it already haha

text: My problem has always been that when you use a specialized tool, it's SO HARD to get other teams into your workflow

elements.text: My problem has always been that when you use a specialized tool, it's SO HARD to get other teams into your workflow

text: I hadn't considered the argument that corporations should or shouldn't create art. In a way, they already have. Montgomery Ward created Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer, which has arguably become part of our culture the way any other art does.

elements.text: I hadn't considered the argument that corporations should or shouldn't create art. In a way, they already have. Montgomery Ward created Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer, which has arguably become part of our culture the way any other art does.

elements.text: Hey
! How does social proof fit into your content strategy and mix?

text: Maybe my background in film and television caused me to more easily ignore the commercial nature of art. In film school, my classmates wanted to be the next auteur and I wanted to be the next Spielberg.

elements.text: i have a question for
. what do you wish all content marketers knew about product marketing?

text: Hey Angela! So with Airtable in particular, we have a product that's REALLY hard to explain without social proof, so it's very important to us

elements.text: Hey Angela! So with Airtable in particular, we have a product that's REALLY hard to explain without social proof, so it's very important to us

text: We're actually currently building out our team to do even more customer storytelling, because we believe we need more customer stories in truly EVERY aspect of our marketing

elements.text: We're actually currently building out our team to do even more customer storytelling, because we believe we need more customer stories in truly EVERY aspect of our marketing

text: And to be fair...most filmmakers (for example) are trying to make money

elements.text: And to be fair...most filmmakers (for example) are trying to make money

elements.text: Plus, if you consider The Church as a company (don’t @ me!), you could say that most art in the last 1000 years was underwritten by business.

text: lol yes we have a rich history of patronage

elements.text: lol yes we have a rich history of patronage

text: I do feel like the patron/artist system is super relevant here...should we just think about tech companies as patrons?

elements.text: I do feel like the patron/artist system is super relevant here...should we just think about tech companies as patrons?

text: Would love a panel about this! My team had an (another) existential crisis when we saw that Hubspot had bought The Hustle, which stirred up bad memories for the former journalists among us. But yes, I agree that this has been a trend that's come and gone multiple times. Has anyone been able to show ROI? (That's what's killed it in the past).

elements.text: Would love a panel about this! My team had an (another) existential crisis when we saw that Hubspot had bought The Hustle, which stirred up bad memories for the former journalists among us. But yes, I agree that this has been a trend that's come and gone multiple times. Has anyone been able to show ROI? (That's what's killed it in the past).

text:
Ah yes! Would love to hear some of the other aspects on your roadmap for building social proof into, or example ways you plan to use this?

Also reminds me of - as an intercom user, I saw (and then of course shared on linkedin) an amazing example of intercom building in a micro case study into their product activation / onboarding - basically said “June at Guru reduced response times by 18%” by using this feature. (I later spoke to their head of onboarding who said they a/b tested this against just a “use this feature” and for a certain user type it made a big difference)

elements.text:
Ah yes! Would love to hear some of the other aspects on your roadmap for building social proof into, or example ways you plan to use this?

text: At the end of the day, we know that brand endeavors (like fancy print mags) have an impact, but they take time to show results (if they ever do show results). And CEOs/boards tend to go through cycles of tolerance for slow/no-producing investements

text: I have a management question: How do you know when it's worth the time and effort to develop and mentor someone?

text: I should also add that some people are good at their jobs (or just OK at their jobs) and don't want to improve. And that is TOTALLY FINE. Not everybody you manage needs to be coached. As long as they aren't doing a bad job, no need for alarm.

elements.text: I should also add that some people are good at their jobs (or just OK at their jobs) and don't want to improve. And that is TOTALLY FINE. Not everybody you manage needs to be coached. As long as they aren't doing a bad job, no need for alarm.

text: the first time airtable "clicked" for me—all of a sudden i realized that i could build things without code—i got hooked. is there a metric for that? can you someone how measure that aha moment for new users?

text: That’s so true.  So it’s all the same as it ever was in function, just the source of the cash is different. Anyway - don’t want the hijack the larger discussion with more random thoughts. Looking forward to the rest of the AMA.

text: <@U011UJX75PE> told me how great airtable was and encouraged me to try it out for a personal use. so made a running log and it was way better than the spreadsheet i used previously. i later started using it for work stuff (like content calendars, a database of examples for sales calls)
